study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a prebiotic mixture (scGOS/lcFOS) in hypoallergenic whey formula could reduce immunoglobulin free light-chain (Ig-fLC) plasma concentrations in infants at risk for allergies.
results_summary: The study found that infants receiving the prebiotic mixture had significantly lower Ig-fLC levels compared to placebo-fed infants, suggesting a potential role for Ig-fLC in atopic dermatitis (AD) pathophysiology. Lambda Ig-fLC concentrations were also positively correlated with total IgE levels.
population_specificity: Infants at high risk for developing allergic diseases.
effective_dosage: 8 g/l of scGOS/lcFOS mixture in hypoallergenic whey formula.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of cranberry proanthocyanidins (PAC) in mitigating metabolic syndrome (MetS) pathophysiology in mice and to uncover the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Cranberry PAC significantly reduced obesity, hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and insulin resistance in mice on a high-fat/high-fructose diet. It also improved cardiovascular risk factors, gut microbiota composition, and reduced inflammation, liver steatosis, and ER stress biomarkers.
population_specificity: Male mice on standard Chow or high-fat/high-fructose (HFHF) diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether probiotic supplementation could prevent eczema development in high-risk infants, some of whom were fed cow's milk formula after 3 months of exclusive breastfeeding.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic supplementation significantly reduced eczema prevalence and cumulative incidence in high-risk infants by 1 year, though no differences were observed in IgE levels or food allergen sensitization. Cow's milk formula was used as part of the feeding regimen but its direct effects were not separately analyzed.
population_specificity: Infants at high risk of allergic diseases (based on family history), fed breastmilk or cow's milk formula from 4-6 months.
effective_dosage: Once-daily probiotic mixture (Bifidobacterium bifidum BGN4, B. lactis AD011, Lactobacillus acidophilus AD031) or placebo.
study_duration: From 4-8 weeks before delivery until 6 months after delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if early-life supplementation of probiotics in cow's milk had any long-term effect on preventing allergic diseases in at-risk infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in allergic outcomes (asthma, allergic rhinitis, eczema, food allergy, or sensitization to inhalant allergens) between the probiotic-supplemented and non-supplemented groups by age 5. Growth rates were similar in both groups.
population_specificity: 253 infants at risk for allergy.
study_duration: From the first day of life to 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of cranberry supplementation on the genitourinary microbiome composition in healthy women.
results_summary: The study found no significant shifts in microbial composition due to cranberry supplementation and no statistically significant differences between the intervention and control groups. The genitourinary microbiome remained stable during supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy women of reproductive age (18-40 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficiency of cranberry extract-infused 3D-printable resins in preventing denture-induced stomatitis and compare their mechanical properties with conventional denture materials.
results_summary: Cranberry-infused 3D-printed dentures showed significantly fewer Candida CFUs, reduced biofilm thickness, and lower surface coverage compared to PMMA dentures. They also exhibited superior flexural strength and fracture toughness.
population_specificity: Fifteen patients aged 45 to 60 with completely edentulous maxillary and mandibular arches.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, mechanisms of action, and research trends of cranberry-derived bioactive compounds, particularly proanthocyanidins (PACs), in preventing urinary tract infections (UTIs).
results_summary: Cranberry metabolites, especially A-type PACs, flavonoids, and phenolic acids, inhibit Escherichia coli adhesion to urothelial cells, reducing UTI recurrence. Gut microbiota-driven transformation of PACs enhances efficacy, while cranberry oligosaccharides disrupt biofilm formation in high-risk populations.
population_specificity: High-risk populations for UTIs (specifics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of novel fungicides from FRAC Groups 7, 9, and 12, alone and in combination with azoxystrobin, in reducing cranberry fruit rot incidence and improving yield.
results_summary: Treatments containing pydiflumetofen, pydiflumetofen & fludioxonil, and benzovindiflupyr, when combined with azoxystrobin, consistently reduced fruit rot incidence and increased yields. Cyprodinil & fludioxonil plus azoxystrobin also showed efficacy in 2021.
population_specificity: Cranberry cultivars 'Demoranville', 'Ben Lear,' and 'Stevens'

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cranberry juice enriched with omega-3 on inflammatory, oxidative stress, and periodontal status in diabetic patients with periodontal disease.
results_summary: Cranberry juice enriched with omega-3 increased serum and salivary antioxidant capacity, reduced oxidative stress markers, and decreased inflammatory markers (hs-CRP, IL-6, TNF-α). It also improved periodontal health by reducing pocket depth and clinical attachment loss.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients (35–67 years old) with periodontal disease.
effective_dosage: 200 mL cranberry juice enriched with 1 g omega-3, twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whole cranberry fruit powder supplements could reduce the incidence of culture-confirmed UTIs and related outcomes in females with a history of recurrent UTIs.
results_summary: The study found that cranberry powder reduced culture-confirmed UTI risk by 52%, delayed the time to first UTI episode, and decreased the mean total number of UTIs per participant. No significant differences were observed for symptomatic suspected UTIs or dysuria, and no safety concerns were reported.
population_specificity: Healthy females aged 18-65 with a history of recurrent UTIs (≥3 UTIs in the last year or ≤2 in the last 6 months).
effective_dosage: 500 mg/d of whole cranberry powder (Pacran) in one capsule.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry phenolic extracts, when functionalized with graphene oxide (GO-CR) and incorporated into a hydrogel, could enhance wound healing in diabetic foot ulcers by improving antimicrobial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The GO-CR nanohybrid significantly improved the hydrogel's stretchability and photothermal conversion, reduced inflammation markers (NLRP3, TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β), and enhanced wound healing in diabetic ulcers.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effects and molecular mechanisms of cranberry-derived exosomes (Va-exos) in treating high-fat and high-sugar diet-induced premature ovarian failure (HFHS-POF) in mice.
results_summary: Va-exos alleviated POF symptoms, improved intestinal barrier function, reduced inflammatory factors, modulated gut microbiota (increasing Akkermansia and Allobaculum, decreasing uncultured-bacterium_f-Muribaculaceae and others), and reduced ovarian granulosa cell PANoptosis.
population_specificity: HFHS-POF model mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a cranberry-based mouth rinse (C-MR) in reducing Streptococcus mutans counts compared to a fluoride mouth rinse (F-MR) in children.
results_summary: The study found that the cranberry mouth rinse was non-inferior to the fluoride mouth rinse in reducing S. mutans counts, with both groups showing significant reductions after one month of use. The inter-group difference was not statistically significant, indicating comparable efficacy.
population_specificity: 280 children aged 8-12 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of anthocyanin-rich cranberry extract on dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in mice, focusing on its potential mechanisms, including ferroptosis regulation and intestinal flora modulation.
results_summary: Cranberry extract alleviated IBD symptoms in mice, improving disease activity index, colon length, and morphology. It modulated ferroptosis-associated genes, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, and influenced intestinal flora balance, though the primary benefit appeared independent of flora changes.
population_specificity: DSS-induced IBD mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of cranberry as a natural alternative to prevent urinary tract infections (UTIs) by inhibiting bacterial adhesion to the urothelium.
results_summary: Cranberry products were found to inhibit the adhesion of uropathogenic bacteria, reducing the likelihood of UTIs, though studies had methodological limitations and small sample sizes. Some encouraging results suggest potential for preventing recurrent UTIs, but optimal dosages and bioavailability require further research.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of urinary tract infections (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cranberry juice, cranberry tablets, and increased liquids on the management of urinary tract infections (UTIs).
results_summary: Cranberry juice consumption resulted in a 54% lower rate of UTIs compared to no treatment and a 27% lower rate than placebo, while also reducing antibiotic use by 49% compared to placebo and 59% compared to no treatment. Cranberry compounds also reduced UTI-associated symptoms.
population_specificity: Women (implied by high UTI prevalence in females, though not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cranberry products in preventing urinary tract infections (UTIs) in patients with urinary diversions.
results_summary: The study found sparse evidence supporting cranberry products' efficacy in preventing UTIs after ileal conduit urinary diversion, with no significant difference in UTI rates or microbiology patterns compared to other diversion types. E. coli remained the most prevalent pathogen, persisting despite antibiotic treatment.
population_specificity: Patients living with urinary diversions (orthoptic diversions, ileal conduit diversions, and continent cutaneous diversions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a tablet containing inactivated Ligilactobacillus salivarius CECT 5317 and cranberry extract could reduce the incidence of initial carious lesions in caries-active preschool children.
results_summary: The study found that the test group had a significantly lower 9-month incidence of initial carious lesions compared to the placebo group, though plaque levels and salivary bacterial counts remained unchanged. The cranberry-containing tablet showed efficacy in reducing early caries development.
population_specificity: Caries-active preschool children (N = 73, with at least one active carious lesion).
study_duration: 3 months (intervention period), with follow-up at 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry has lipid-lowering and hypoglycemic properties in humans by analyzing existing studies.
results_summary: Cranberry consumption significantly reduced the total cholesterol to HDL-C ratio and HOMA-IR but did not affect other lipid or glycemic parameters. Subgroup analysis showed dried cranberry forms reduced fasting insulin levels, while other factors like dosage and health conditions had no impact.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cranberry-derived proanthocyanidin (PAC) and its microbial metabolite HPPA affect inflammatory microRNA responses in human intestinal epithelial cells.
results_summary: The study found that cranberry PAC and its metabolite 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid partially reversed pro-inflammatory microRNA responses in intestinal cells, but HPPA did not show the same effect. The data suggest cranberry components may combat inflammation, though effects vary by metabolite.
population_specificity: Caco-2BBe1 human intestinal epithelial cells
effective_dosage: Cranberry extract (50 µg/ml or 100 µg/ml), HPPA (5 µg/ml or 10 µg/ml)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nephroprotective effects of Vaccinium oxycoccos (cranberry) in mice with streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy.
results_summary: The study found that V. oxycoccos (400 mg/kg) significantly improved serum and urine parameters, reduced weight loss, lowered blood glucose, and exhibited antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects in diabetic mice. The highest dose showed the most pronounced benefits, including improved HDL, insulin, SOD, GSH, and reduced inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Male mice with streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg, administered orally daily by gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry proanthocyanidins (C-PACs) mitigate bile reflux-induced transporter dysregulation to prevent esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC).
results_summary: C-PACs significantly altered reflux-induced changes in ABC and SLC transporters, restoring normal function and reducing EAC progression by 83%. The study also linked these findings to human EAC patient data, suggesting translational relevance.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to reflux, with translational relevance assessed using human EAC patient biopsies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of cranberry extract on patients with simple urinary tract infections compared to fosfomycin treatment.
results_summary: Cranberry use resulted in similar leukocyte levels as fosfomycin, with higher well-being reported on days 3 and 7. The cranberry group showed significantly better well-being by day 7 compared to the antibiotic group.
population_specificity: Patients with simple-type urinary tract infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chemical composition and potential insulin resistance (IR) correction effect of American cranberry leaf extracts and develop a novel 3D-printed oral dosage form for these extracts.
results_summary: The study found that cranberry leaf extracts improved insulin sensitivity and affected IR levels and liver lipid content in rats with experimental IR. A novel 3D-printed immediate-release dosage form was successfully developed for oral administration of the extracts.
population_specificity: Rats with experimental insulin resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry could counteract UPEC-induced damage to urinary epithelial cell integrity, permeability, barrier functions, oxidative stress, and PD-L1 expression.
results_summary: Cranberry (3 mg/mL) protected against UPEC-induced reductions in cell viability and monolayer integrity, mitigated damage to cell barrier integrity, reduced oxidative stress, and countered UPEC/TNFα-triggered PD-L1 expression. No protective effects were observed for D-mannose or ibuprofen.
population_specificity: Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cell line, a urinary tract epithelial cell model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of cranberry against phenobarbital-induced testicular toxicity in rats.
results_summary: Cranberry significantly restored antioxidant enzyme activities, reduced oxidative stress markers, and improved testicular histology. Co-treatment with cranberry and vitamin C showed the most pronounced protective effects, including reduced apoptosis.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify plasma and urine (poly)phenol metabolites after cranberry powder intake in healthy older adults and investigate inter-individual differences in metabolism.
results_summary: Cranberry consumption altered plasma metabolites, primarily hydroxycinnamates and hippuric acid, and identified three distinct urinary metabotypes driven by colonic metabolism. Metabotype allocation remained consistent after 12 weeks, highlighting gut microbiota-driven variability in (poly)phenol metabolism.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a polyberry gel containing cranberry extract in treating chronic periodontitis compared to standard treatments.
results_summary: The polyberry gel significantly reduced periodontitis parameters (PI, GI, PPD, CAL, AST, CRP) and was comparable to tetracycline treatment, likely due to its antioxidant polyphenolic constituents.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic periodontitis and probing pocket depth up to 5 mm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of 6% cranberry solution as a reversal agent for enamel surface properties after bleaching with different methods.
results_summary: The study found that 6% cranberry solution as a reversal agent showed mixed results—it was associated with the least surface microhardness (SMH) when used with 40% hydrogen peroxide but the least surface roughness (Ra) when used with Zinc Phthalocyanine activated by PDT.
population_specificity: Extracted human mandibular molars (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 6% cranberry solution (used as a reversal agent).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a mixture of cranberry extract and chondroitin sulfate forms a crosslinked structure with barrier properties and its antibiofilm effects against Escherichia coli strains.
results_summary: The study found that the cranberry-chondroitin sulfate mixture formed a crosslinked structure with barrier properties, confirmed via microscopy and TEER measurements. The precipitate showed variable inhibitory effects on biofilm formation, particularly in antibiotic-resistant UTI strains.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of feeding cranberry vine pellet (CVP) on ewes' body weights, milk quality, and lambs' growth parameters during late gestation and lactation.
results_summary: CVP reduced milk fat and solids while increasing milk urea nitrogen in ewes, but no significant differences were found in body condition scores, milk protein, or lamb growth measurements.
population_specificity: 41 Dorset ewes during late gestation and lactation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of cranberry extract in inhibiting the growth of lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) cells and its potential molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Cranberry extract reduced A549 LUAD cell proliferation, increased caspase-3 activity (indicating apoptosis), and downregulated pro-proliferation molecules (cyclin E, CDK2, CDK4) and anti-apoptotic molecules (caspase 8, FLIP).
population_specificity: A549 lung adenocarcinoma cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for cranberry as a nonantibiotic option for preventing or treating UTIs in adult women.
results_summary: The study found conflicting evidence regarding cranberry's effectiveness in preventing or treating UTIs, with multiple studies producing mixed results. Larger, more rigorous trials are needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Adult women with uncomplicated UTIs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of cranberry proanthocyanidins (PACs) in improving metabolic syndrome (MetS) pathological conditions and liver complications in mice.
results_summary: PACs reduced obesity, insulin resistance, hyperlipidemia, oxidative stress, and inflammation in mice fed a high-fat/high-sucrose diet. They also improved hepatic steatosis by inhibiting lipogenesis and stimulating beta-oxidation, while downregulating liver gluconeogenesis enzymes.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and validate urinary biomarkers of cranberry juice intake and assess their potential role in explaining cranberry's UTI-preventive effects.
results_summary: The study identified 26-27 discriminant urinary metabolites after cranberry consumption, including quinic acid and hippuric acid, which could classify consumers with 84.4%-100% accuracy. The double-blind study validated findings from a prior open-label study, suggesting these metabolites may relate to cranberry's UTI prevention.
population_specificity: 16 healthy women aged 18-29 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of cranberry non-dialyzable material (NDM) on fasting blood glucose levels in genetically diverse mice under different diets and sexes.
results_summary: Cranberry NDM significantly lowered fasting blood glucose in mice on a standard chow diet but showed non-significant effects in mice on a high-fat diet, with efficacy varying by genetic background, sex, and diet.
population_specificity: Genetically diverse Collaborative Cross (CC) mice (male and female) on standard chow or high-fat diets.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg intraperitoneal injection, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry syrup waste could enhance enhanced biological phosphorus removal (EBPR) performance in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that adding cranberry syrup waste to the RAS fermentation process improved phosphorus removal, achieving 90% TP removal without chemical addition. The operational changes, including cranberry syrup waste addition, enriched phosphorus-accumulating organisms (PAOs) and optimized the process.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment plant (WRWWTP) infrastructure and microbial communities.
effective_dosage: Not specified (cranberry syrup waste was added as a carbon source, but exact dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Pilot testing began in April 2021; exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of enzymatic hydrolysis on cranberry pomace's dietary fiber, bioactive compounds, prebiotic activity, and technological properties.
results_summary: Enzymatic treatment increased short-chain soluble saccharides and oligosaccharide content, promoted probiotic growth, and altered dietary fiber composition. Total phenolic content and water swelling capacity improved with specific enzymes, while oil and water retention capacities generally decreased.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using probiotic strains and enzymatic treatments).
effective_dosage: Not specified (enzyme concentrations and treatment conditions not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of enzymatic hydrolysis not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate non-antibiotic means, including cranberry, for preventing UTIs in pediatric populations.
results_summary: The study found that cranberry extract/juice shows potential in UTI prevention through competitive inhibition of uropathogens, but significant heterogeneity among studies limits definitive recommendations.
population_specificity: Pediatric population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of cranberry juice and extract on reducing dentin erosion in vitro, focusing on their inhibitory action on matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs).
results_summary: Cranberry juice and extract significantly reduced dentin erosion compared to the control, with results comparable to green tea extract (EGCg). The study suggests cranberry's MMP-inhibiting properties may contribute to this protective effect despite its low pH.
population_specificity: Bovine dentin specimens (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 10% cranberry extract (CrE) and commercial cranberry juice (CrJ, Cranberry JuxxTM), applied for 1 min after acid challenges.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neuroprotective potential of cranberry juice against Parkinson's disease in a rotenone-induced rat model.
results_summary: Cranberry juice treatment reduced α-synuclein accumulation, decreased apoptosis markers (Bax and cleaved caspase-9), normalized cytochrome c levels, and improved postural instability, indicating neuroprotection. However, long-term high-dose administration alone showed potential deleterious effects on midbrain cell survival.
population_specificity: Wistar rats
study_duration: 45 days (10 days pre-treatment, 35 days combined treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of daily cranberry polyphenol oral rinse on taste perception, salivary proteins, and oral microbiota, particularly in relation to TAS2R38 bitter taste genetics.
results_summary: The cranberry polyphenol extract (CPE) modified the oral microbiome composition in non-tasters (NTs) to resemble that of super-tasters (STs) but had no effect on STs. The intervention altered specific salivary protein levels without changing sensory perception.
population_specificity: PROP super-tasters (ST, n = 10) and non-tasters (NT, n = 10).
effective_dosage: 30 mL of 0.75 g/L CPE, twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute and daily consumption of whole cranberry powder improves vascular function in healthy men and how these effects relate to circulating cranberry (poly)phenol metabolites.
results_summary: Cranberry consumption significantly improved flow-mediated dilation (FMD) at 2 hours and after 1 month, but did not affect other vascular measures like pulse wave velocity, blood pressure, or blood lipids. Specific (poly)phenol metabolites in plasma were linked to the observed vascular benefits.
population_specificity: 45 healthy male adults
effective_dosage: 9 g cranberry powder daily (equivalent to 100 g fresh cranberries, 525 mg total (poly)phenols)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory mechanisms of cranberry polyphenol extracts (C-PAC and AFG) on premalignant Barrett's esophagus (BE) and esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) cell lines.
results_summary: C-PAC was more potent than AFG at inducing cell death in BE and EAC cell lines, modulating multiple cancer-associated pathways, including NOTCH signaling, immune response, and epithelial to mesenchymal transition. The study identified new mechanisms by which cranberry polyphenols may inhibit EAC.
population_specificity: Premalignant Barrett's esophagus (BE) and esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) cell lines (JH-EsoAd1 and OE19).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry capsules combined with methenamine hippurate could effectively reduce urinary tract infection (UTI) rates after pelvic reconstructive surgery in patients requiring short-term catheterization.
results_summary: The study found that cranberry with methenamine significantly reduced UTI rates at 1 week (66.7% vs. 79.8% in the placebo group) and 6 weeks postoperatively (72.0% vs. 89.9%), with fewer pseudomonal UTIs in the treatment group. Overall adherence and satisfaction were high, and the combination was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients discharged with a catheter after pelvic reconstructive surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (cranberry capsules combined with methenamine hippurate).
study_duration: Intervention effects were assessed at 1 week and 6 weeks postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective effect of Cranberry Water Extract (CWE) on estrogen-induced cholestasis in rats.
results_summary: CWE improved serum cholesterol, bile acid, and TBIL levels, enhanced hepatic antioxidant activity (SOD, GPx), and reduced markers of liver damage (ALP, ALT, γ-GT) and inflammation (TNF-α, NO, MMP-2, MMP-9, MDA). It also downregulated liver TLR4, NF-κB, and p38MAPK gene expression.
population_specificity: Adult albino rats weighing approximately 150±10 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether cranberry dry extract supplementation could reduce plasma levels of LPS and uremic toxins (IS, p-CS, IAA) in non-dialysis CKD patients by modulating gut microbiota.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in LPS or uremic toxin levels after two months of cranberry supplementation compared to placebo. No adverse effects were reported, but the intervention did not achieve its intended outcomes.
population_specificity: Non-dialysis Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) patients (n=25, 56-59 years, eGFR ~39 mL/min).
effective_dosage: 500 mg dry cranberry extract, twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether encapsulating cranberry extract (CBE) in bile salt augmented liposomes (BSALs) could enhance its bioavailability and hepatoprotective effects against DMN-induced liver injury in rats.
results_summary: The optimized BSALs formulation (F1) significantly improved CBE's hepatoprotective effects, reducing liver injury markers (ALT, AST, ALP, MDA) and increasing antioxidant levels (GSH, SOD, GPX). F1 also exhibited anti-inflammatory and antifibrotic properties by suppressing inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, MCP-1, IL-6) and downregulating mRNA levels of VEGF-C, STAT-3, and IFN-γ.
population_specificity: Rats with DMN-induced liver injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impacts of daily cranberry juice consumption and its deacidification on intestinal inflammation and gut microbiota in mice.
results_summary: Cranberry juice did not induce intestinal inflammation but increased gut microbiota diversity and modulated its functions. Deacidification further increased beneficial bacteria (Lachnospiraceae family) without reducing inflammation.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of cranberry supplementation on liver enzymes, hepatic steatosis, and cardiometabolic risk factors in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Cranberry supplementation significantly improved lipid profiles (total cholesterol and triglycerides), insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), and hepatic steatosis compared to placebo, but did not significantly affect liver enzyme levels.
population_specificity: 110 patients with NAFLD (mean age 43.16 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cranberry juice (CJ) and a cranberry functional beverage (CFB) on the growth and metabolic activity of selected oral bacteria, including Actinomyces naeslundii, Streptococcus mutans, and Lactobacillus paracasei subsp. paracasei.
results_summary: CJ and CFB exhibited varying antimicrobial effects on the tested bacteria, with CJ showing bactericidal effects on S. mutans and A. naeslundii being more sensitive to CJ. CFB was effective against S. mutans and A. naeslundii but had minimal impact on L. paracasei subsp. paracasei, suggesting potential as an adjunct in oral disease treatment.
population_specificity: Oral bacteria (Actinomyces naeslundii, Streptococcus mutans, Lactobacillus paracasei subsp. paracasei) in vitro.
effective_dosage: CJ at 0.03125-0.5 mL/mL; CFB (80% apple juice, 20% CJ, 0.25 g/100 mL cinnamon).
study_duration: 48-hour electrical impedance measurements (EIM) and serial dilution pour plate method (SDPP) assessments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry supplementation improves H. pylori eradication rates in H. pylori-positive individuals.
results_summary: Cranberry supplementation increased the chance of H. pylori eradication by 1.27 times, but this effect was not statistically significant. The study noted moderate heterogeneity among the included trials.
population_specificity: H. pylori-positive adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiviral activity of cranberry extract against Hazara virus (HAZV) as a surrogate model for Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV).
results_summary: The cranberry extract demonstrated antiviral activity against HAZV by targeting early stages of viral replication, including adsorption to target cells, and showed a virucidal effect through direct interaction with viral particles. The antiviral effect was also confirmed for CCHFV.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify different metabolic phenotypes (metabotypes) related to the urinary excretion of flavan-3-ol metabolites after cranberry consumption and assess the impact of statistical techniques on metabotyping.
results_summary: The study found that data pre-treatment significantly influenced PCA models, while cluster analysis and PLS-DA validated urinary metabotypes, highlighting inter-individual variability in flavan-3-ol metabolism. The methodological approach was robust, emphasizing the importance of data pre-treatment and clustering methods.
population_specificity: Human participants from two intervention studies (acute and chronic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of cranberry as adjuvant therapy in reducing urinary tract infection (UTI) recurrence in susceptible populations.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that cranberry-based products significantly reduced UTI incidence in susceptible populations, with relative risk reductions of 32% in women with recurrent UTIs, 45% in children, and 51% in patients using indwelling catheters. Cranberry juice showed a 35% greater risk reduction compared to capsules or tablets.
population_specificity: Susceptible populations, including women with recurrent UTIs, children, and patients using indwelling catheters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant properties of cranberry extract and its potential to mitigate oxidative stress and organ damage induced by ethylene oxide (EtO) in rats.
results_summary: Cranberry extract significantly increased antioxidant levels (SOD, CAT, GSH) and reduced oxidative stress markers (AOPPs, MDA). It also reversed histopathological damage in vital organs caused by EtO.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to ethylene oxide-induced oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry dietary supplementation affects fecal concentrations of thermotolerant coliforms, Enterococcus spp., and Lactobacillus spp. in rats.
results_summary: Cranberry supplementation did not significantly alter fecal bacterial concentrations in the overall rat population, though some individual rats showed changes in thermotolerant coliforms and Enterococcus spp. No effect on body weight or feed intake was observed.
population_specificity: Wistar rats housed in individual cages.
effective_dosage: Standard diet supplemented with cranberry powder containing 10.9 mg/100 g of proanthocyanidin-type polyphenols (PAC).
study_duration: 7 days per diet, with a 7-day wash-out period in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry juice supplementation could modify emerging cardiovascular disease risk factors, such as central vascular function and HDL efflux, in middle-aged adults with overweight/obesity and elevated blood pressure.
results_summary: Cranberry juice had no significant effect on central systolic blood pressure but modestly reduced 24-h diastolic ambulatory BP and altered the lipoprotein profile by increasing large LDL-C particles and LDL size. No significant effect was observed on HDL efflux in the total population, though exploratory analyses suggested potential benefits in overweight participants.
population_specificity: Middle-aged adults with overweight/obesity (mean BMI: 28.7 ± 0.8 kg/m²; mean age: 47 ± 2 years) and elevated brachial blood pressure.
study_duration: 8-week supplementation periods with an 8-week compliance break (crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of polyphenol-rich cranberry extract (NDM-CRE) on body weight loss in genetically diverse mouse lines fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: NDM-CRE induced significant body weight reduction in 5 out of 13 male and 5 out of 13 female mouse lines, with varying responses across genetic backgrounds. No significant changes were observed in the remaining lines, and one male line showed a significant increase in body weight.
population_specificity: Genetically diverse collaborative cross (CC) mouse lines fed a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: 50 mg kg-1, injected intraperitoneally 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry juice could counteract rotenone-induced oxidative stress in the brain, liver, and kidney of rats.
results_summary: Cranberry juice showed a protective effect against rotenone-induced oxidative damage in the brain and reduced serum hepatic enzyme activity, but its effects on antioxidant enzymes were inconsistent across organs.
population_specificity: Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry extract could reduce lower urinary tract (LUT) and gastrointestinal (GI) signs in cats with feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC).
results_summary: The study found that cranberry extract led to the disappearance of LUT signs by day 60 and showed significant improvement in GI signs and bladder ultrasonography in treated cats, while urinalysis results did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: Client-owned cats with feline idiopathic cystitis (FIC).
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily oral nutritional supplement containing cranberry extract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the short-term effects of a PAC-rich cranberry juice extract (CJE) on the dynamics of a human-derived bacterial community in a gnotobiotic mouse model.
results_summary: Daily administration of CJE induced distinct dynamic patterns in bacterial abundances, increasing Akkermansia muciniphila and Clostridium hiranonis while reducing Bacteroides ovatus after treatment cessation. The microbiome resiliently returned to pre-treatment levels post-intervention.
population_specificity: Gnotobiotic mouse model with a human-derived bacterial community.
study_duration: 10-day intervention with a 14-day recovery phase (total 37-day experiment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-adhesion activity (AAA) of two commercial cranberry supplement products (juice extract vs. whole berry blend) and assess the influence of proanthocyanidin (PAC) solubility on their effectiveness.
results_summary: The cranberry juice extract product had higher soluble PAC content and significantly greater urinary AAA compared to the whole berry blended product, which contained mainly insoluble PACs. Only fractions with soluble PACs showed in vitro AAA.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general adult population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a high-dose cranberry proanthocyanidin extract could prevent recurrent urinary tract infections in women with a history of such infections.
results_summary: The high-dose cranberry extract showed a non-significant 24% decrease in symptomatic urinary tract infections overall, but post-hoc analysis revealed a significant reduction in women with fewer than 5 infections per year. No major side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Healthy adult women with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (≥2 in 6 months or ≥3 in 12 months).
effective_dosage: High dose: 2 × 18.5 mg daily; low dose (control): 2 × 1 mg daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether cranberry-extracted proanthocyanidins (cPAC) could overcome β-lactam resistance mechanisms (ESBL, MBL, and PBP2a) in bacteria.
results_summary: The study found that cPAC potentiated various β-lactams against resistant bacteria, inhibited β-lactamase activity (including ESBL and MBL), and selectively enhanced oxacillin and carbenicillin against methicillin-resistant staphylococci. The results suggest cPAC may help counteract β-lactam resistance.
population_specificity: β-lactam-resistant Enterobacteriaceae clinical isolates and ESBL- and MBL-producing E. coli, as well as methicillin-resistant staphylococci.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if cranberry extract (CE) could sensitize glioblastoma cells to radiotherapy (RT) by inhibiting proliferation and promoting apoptosis.
results_summary: CE alone had minimal effect on U87 cell survival, but when combined with RT, it significantly inhibited proliferation and promoted apoptosis compared to RT alone. These effects were linked to up-regulation of p21 and down-regulation of cyclin B, cyclin-dependent kinase 4, and survivin.
population_specificity: Human glioblastoma cell line U87.

study_goal: To determine the feasibility of conducting a randomized trial on the effectiveness of cranberry extract in reducing antibiotic use for women with acute, uncomplicated UTI symptoms.
results_summary: The study found it feasible to conduct a trial on cranberry extract for UTI treatment, with high recruitment rates and diary completion. No serious adverse events were reported, and some participants in the control group consumed cranberry products.
population_specificity: Women aged 18+ with symptoms of acute, uncomplicated UTI presenting at general practices in Oxfordshire.
effective_dosage: Cranberry capsules for up to 7 days (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of cranberry fruit by-products in modulating immunity in broiler chickens as an alternative to antibiotics.
results_summary: Cranberry pomace and ethanolic extract supplementation modulated innate immune responses and suppressed proinflammatory cytokines in broilers, with specific gene expression changes observed in the liver and bursa of Fabricius. The highest IgY levels were found in birds fed 2% cranberry pomace.
population_specificity: Broiler Cobb 500 chicks
effective_dosage: Cranberry pomace at 1% and 2%, cranberry pomace ethanolic extract at 150 and 300 ppm

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether cranberry powder (CR) is effective for treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in a rat model.
results_summary: The CR8W group showed significant reductions in prostate weight (33%), DHT levels (18% in serum, 28% in prostate), and 5-alpha reductase levels (18% type 1, 35% type 2), indicating CR may attenuate BPH by inhibiting these biomarkers.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (200-250 g) with BPH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a nutraceutical compound containing cranberry (among other ingredients) in preventing recurrent UTIs in menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that the nutraceutical compound significantly reduced the number of UTIs and improved symptoms in menopausal women at 6 and 12 months compared to the control group. The improvement was statistically significant, as measured by the reduction in VAS scale values.
population_specificity: Menopausal women with a history of recurrent UTIs.
effective_dosage: The drug was taken for ten days every month (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial action of cranberry anthocyanin (CA) against Staphylococcus aureus and its potential as a natural preservative in cooked meat.
results_summary: CA demonstrated strong antibacterial effects against S. aureus, reducing bacterial counts, intracellular ATP, and protein levels while damaging cell membranes. Applied to cooked pork and beef, CA significantly decreased S. aureus counts and pH values, though it caused color-darkening.
population_specificity: In vitro study on S. aureus strains and cooked meat samples.
study_duration: Short-term (0.5 hours for antibacterial tests; storage duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether concurrent omega-3 and cranberry juice supplementation enhances the efficacy of standard antibiotic therapy in eradicating Helicobacter pylori infection and improving gastrointestinal symptoms and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: The study is in the early stages of sampling, so no results regarding cranberry's effects are available yet.
population_specificity: Adults with Helicobacter pylori infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify new pancreatic lipase inhibitors from cranberry anthocyanins as potential natural alternatives to orlistat for obesity treatment.
results_summary: Four cranberry anthocyanins (C3A, C3Ga, Pn3A, Pn3Ga) were discovered as potent pancreatic lipase inhibitors, with C3A showing the highest binding capacity and impact on enzyme structure. The study suggested cranberry anthocyanins could be developed as food supplements for obesity prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and computational study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of a combination supplement containing cranberry (Lactoflorene Cist®) in preventing recurrent uncomplicated UTIs in premenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that both treatment regimens (10 days/month for 90 days and daily for 90 days) significantly reduced UTI recurrence compared to the control group (16.0% and 15.5% vs. 52.9%). No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women aged 18-50 years with a history of recurrent uncomplicated UTIs.
effective_dosage: Lactoflorene Cist® once a day for 10 days/month for 90 days (Group 1) or once daily for 90 days (Group 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cranberry extract combined with D-mannose in treating and preventing uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections in women, compared to standard antibiotic therapy.
results_summary: The study found higher cure rates at day 7 when cranberry extract plus D-mannose was added to antibiotics (91.6% vs. 84.4%), with significantly better outcomes in antibiotic-resistant strains (88.8% vs. 37.5%). The combination showed promise in improving antimicrobial sensitivity.
population_specificity: Non-pregnant, otherwise healthy women (mean age 39.77±10.36) with uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections.
study_duration: Initial treatment phase (7 days), followed by a 21-day prophylaxis phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the protective effects of cranberry against urinary tract infections (UTIs), including its mechanisms, efficacy, and potential combined formulations with probiotics.
results_summary: The abstract highlights cranberry's beneficial effects against UTIs, particularly in preventing recurrence and addressing antibiotic resistance, while also noting emerging research on probiotics and combined formulations. It mentions the need for further understanding of cranberry's protective mechanisms.
population_specificity: Primarily healthy females, given the focus on UTIs and their high recurrence rates in this group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dosage effect of daily cranberry consumption on Helicobacter pylori suppression in infected adults, assessing its potential as a complementary management strategy in high-risk regions.
results_summary: High-proanthocyanidin cranberry juice (44 mg twice daily) reduced H. pylori infection rates by 20% after 8 weeks, showing a statistically significant positive trend over time, while encapsulated cranberry powder was ineffective. The intervention was well-tolerated with high compliance.
population_specificity: 522 H. pylori-positive adults in a region with high gastric cancer risk and high H. pylori prevalence.
effective_dosage: 44 mg proanthocyanidin per 240-mL serving, consumed once or twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop effective formulations of natural cranberry extract for preventing and treating biofilm formation on dental surfaces.
results_summary: The study found that formulations combining stearic acid with PVP or LAE achieved higher loading and sustained release of cranberry extract compared to PLGA microencapsulation, effectively inhibiting biofilm growth when incubated with saliva. Two successful formulations (preventative and treatment-based) were developed.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study with saliva incubation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of cranberry pomace as a source of nondigestible oligosaccharides using microwave-assisted and enzymatic extraction methods.
results_summary: The study found that microwave-assisted extraction yielded 21.3% total sugars, mainly oligosaccharides with a degree of polymerization of 7-10, while enzymatic extraction yielded 23.4% to 42.0%, producing shorter oligosaccharides (2-5). The extracts differed in monosaccharide composition, with microwave-assisted extracts enriched in pectic oligosaccharides and enzymatic extracts enriched in glucans.
population_specificity: Industrial cranberry pomace (not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanism of a cranberry polyphenolic extract (CPE) on obesity, glucose metabolism, and energy expenditure in high-fat diet-fed obese mice.
results_summary: CPE treatment reduced body weight by 22.5% compared to the high-fat diet group, increased energy expenditure, and promoted brown adipose tissue thermogenesis and white adipose tissue browning, though it did not fully normalize weight to the level of the normal diet group.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice (4 weeks old) fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory activity, macrophage polarization properties, and cell viability effects of cranberry concentrates (A-type PACs) on human gingival fibroblasts, osteoblasts, and macrophages.
results_summary: Cranberry concentrates did not reduce cell viability and downregulated pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-8, IL-6) while upregulating anti-inflammatory IL-10 in LPS-stimulated macrophages. M1 polarization decreased, and M2 polarization increased in treated macrophages.
population_specificity: Human gingival fibroblasts (HFIB-G cell line), osteosarcoma-derived osteoblasts (SAOS-2 cell line), and THP-1-derived macrophages.
effective_dosage: 25, 50, and 100 µg/mL for 120 seconds, 1 hour, and 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of cranberry capsules in managing symptoms of acute radiation cystitis in prostate cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy.
results_summary: Cranberry capsules performed significantly worse than placebo in improving daytime frequency and bladder control, as measured by the RICAS scale. No significant difference was found between cranberry and placebo in overall cystitis severity.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy at three New Zealand hospitals.
study_duration: During radiation therapy and for two weeks after completion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define the mechanism by which cranberry extracts induce apoptosis in HL-60 cancer cells.
results_summary: Cranberry extracts increased caspase-9 and caspases-3/7 activity, enhanced mitochondrial outer membrane permeability, and reduced AKT phosphorylation, leading to intrinsic apoptosis in HL-60 cells.
population_specificity: HL-60 leukemia cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of cranberries for the treatment of urinary tract infections.
results_summary: The study found that evidence for cranberry's efficacy varies, with insufficient standardization of herbal medicines potentially affecting reproducibility of findings. The abstract does not provide specific results on cranberry's effectiveness for UTIs.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a mix containing cranberry (Novex®) in managing mild to moderate lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in patients with benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: The study found that the cranberry-containing mix significantly improved IPSS and uQoL scores over 90 days, with a mild beneficial effect on erectile function. The improvements were statistically significant for symptom relief and quality of life.
population_specificity: Male patients aged ≥40 years with mild to moderate LUTS due to BPH, excluding those with IPSS >19 or age >80 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the absorption, metabolism, and urinary excretion of cranberry flavan-3-ols, focusing on phenyl-γ-valerolactones and phenylvaleric acids as potential biomarkers of intake.
results_summary: The study found that glucuronide and sulfate conjugates of 5-(3',4'-dihydroxyphenyl)-γ-valerolactone were the main circulating and excreted metabolites after cranberry juice intake, showing a clear dose-dependent relationship. High inter-individual variability in metabolite levels was observed, with some subjects displaying greater efficiency in metabolizing flavan-3-ols.
population_specificity: Ten healthy males
effective_dosage: 375, 716, 1131, 1396, and 1741 mg of total flavan-3-ols in a cranberry juice drink
study_duration: Acute crossover trial with one-week washout

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of chicken eggshell powder (CESP) addition on the phytochemical properties, mineral content, and sensory attributes of cranberry juice.
results_summary: CESP addition enriched cranberry juice with minerals, significantly increased calcium content (66.3 times), reduced acidity, improved taste, and did not significantly alter polyphenolic content or antioxidative activity. Heat treatment caused only a 4% loss of polyphenolic compounds in CESP-supplemented juice compared to 6% in non-supplemented juice.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on cranberry juice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry pectic oligosaccharides (cPOS) could inhibit quiescence and reduce persister cell populations in uropathogenic E. coli.
results_summary: The study found that cranberry pectic oligosaccharides (cPOS) inhibited quiescence and reduced persister cell populations in the uropathogenic E. coli strain CFT073, suggesting potential for UTI prevention.
population_specificity: Uropathogenic E. coli strain CFT073 (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a full trial evaluating cranberry extract's effectiveness in reducing antibiotic use for acute uncomplicated UTIs in women and to preliminarily assess its potential to reduce symptom burden.
results_summary: The study did not report definitive efficacy results but focused on feasibility and preliminary assessment, indicating a need for further research to determine cranberry's impact on antibiotic use and symptom relief.
population_specificity: Women consulting in primary care with symptoms suggestive of uncomplicated UTIs.
effective_dosage: 7-day course of cranberry capsules (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cysticlean® (a cranberry product) could reduce the expression of virulence factors and β-lactamases in cephalosporin-resistant E. coli CTXM-15.
results_summary: Cysticlean® significantly reduced the expression of all ten selected genes encoding virulence factors and β-lactamases in E. coli CTXM-15, suggesting potential as an alternative for preventing recurrent UTIs caused by multi-drug resistant bacteria.
population_specificity: Cephalosporin-resistant E. coli CTXM-15 (NCTC 1553 isolate).
effective_dosage: 240 mg of proanthocyanins (PACs) per capsule (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cranberry proanthocyanidins (PACs) on gene expression and cytotoxic activities of leukotoxin (LtxA) produced by Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans.
results_summary: Cranberry PACs dose-dependently reduced leukotoxin operon gene expression, protected macrophages from LtxA cytotoxicity, decreased caspase-1 activation and inflammatory cytokine release, and blocked LtxA binding to macrophages.
population_specificity: Human macrophages and Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans bacterial strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a fluorescent sensor using carbon dots derived from cranberry beans for detecting Fe3+ ions.
results_summary: The study successfully synthesized carbon dots from cranberry beans, which exhibited stable fluorescence and effectively detected Fe3+ ions within 3 minutes, with a detection limit of 9.55 μM and a wide concentration range of 30-600 μM.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-inflammatory effects of cranberry polyphenol and volatile extracts on nitric oxide (NO) production in LPS-activated macrophages.
results_summary: Cranberry polyphenol and volatile extracts significantly reduced NO production (13-62%) when applied before or after LPS-induced inflammation, with α-terpineol also showing effectiveness at concentrations found in fresh cranberries.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophages (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Polyphenol treatments (317.8 and 635.7 μg g-1), volatile treatments (1.8 and 0.9 μg g-1), and α-terpineol (1.16 μg mL-1)
study_duration: 1-hour pre- or post-treatment before 24-hour LPS application

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the urinary anti-adhesion activity of a cranberry supplement against type 1 and P-type uropathogenic E. coli after consumption.
results_summary: The cranberry supplement showed significantly greater anti-adhesion activity against P-type E. coli at most time points and against type 1 E. coli at 3-9 hours post-consumption compared to placebo. The results suggest potential benefits for urinary tract health.
population_specificity: 20 subjects in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover pilot trial.
effective_dosage: Two cranberry chews per day (one in the morning and one in the evening).
study_duration: Urine samples were collected up to 36 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry components modulate the gut microbiota to reduce Enterobacteriaceae (including uropathogenic E. coli) and increase Bacteroidaceae, potentially explaining its reputed benefits in reducing UTI recurrence.
results_summary: Cranberry extracts and whole cranberry powder reduced Enterobacteriaceae and increased Bacteroidaceae in a human gut microbiome-derived community. Salicylate, a cranberry compound, exhibited antimicrobial activity against E. coli and similarly modulated gut microbiota composition in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Human gut microbiome-derived community (in vitro gut simulator) and laboratory/human UTI E. coli isolates.
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested extracts, powder, and isolated compounds like salicylate in varying doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory effects of dietary cranberry in a mouse model of colitis and its impact on gut microbiota.
results_summary: Cranberry significantly reduced colitis severity, lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines, and improved gut microbiota diversity by increasing beneficial bacteria (e.g., Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium) and decreasing harmful bacteria (e.g., Sutterella, Bilophila).
population_specificity: DSS-treated mice with induced colitis.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of Bio-Kult Pro-Cyan (containing cranberry extract) for preventing recurrent UTIs in pre-menopausal adult women.
results_summary: BKPro-Cyan significantly reduced recurrent UTIs compared to placebo (9.1% vs 33.3%), increased the number of UTI-free subjects (90% vs 67%), prolonged time to first UTI (174 vs 90 days), and reduced antibiotic use (3 vs 11 subjects).
population_specificity: Pre-menopausal adult women with recurrent UTIs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cranberry supplementation could mitigate metabolic disturbances, including non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), in high-fat diet-fed mice.
results_summary: Cranberry supplementation reduced oxidative stress, lowered body weight, decreased serum triglycerides, and improved NAFLD markers, including reduced lipid-droplet formation and hepatocyte ballooning in mice.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed C57BL/6 mice.
study_duration: From 1 week after diet initiation to the end of the study (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between dairy products and cancer risk, focusing on whether dairy consumption decreases cancer risk.
results_summary: The study found that dairy products were among the factors that decrease the risk of cancer, with evidence graded as convincing or probable. No adverse effects or increased risks were associated with dairy consumption in the context of cancer prevention.
population_specificity: General population (data derived from meta-analyses, pooled analyses, or intervention trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiometabolic effects of dairy fat and other dietary components, focusing on their role in modern dietary and policy priorities for cardiovascular diseases, obesity, and diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study suggests yogurt as part of evidence-informed dietary priorities for improved cardiometabolic health, while noting the need for further investigation into the effects of dairy fat and probiotics.
population_specificity: General population with a focus on cardiometabolic health.

study_goal: The study aimed to assess changes in the packing of dairy and other food groups in children's lunches as part of a behavioral nutrition intervention.
results_summary: The study did not report significant changes in dairy servings, focusing instead on increases in vegetables and whole grains and a reduction in sweets. Dairy servings were observed but not highlighted in the results.
population_specificity: Families with preschool-aged children attending Early Care and Education (ECE) centers in Texas, USA.
study_duration: Five-week intervention with a one-week booster three months later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of lactose in infant feeding, its potential role in infantile colic, and the implications of lactose intolerance in different populations.
results_summary: The study found that lactose has a bifidogenic effect and improves calcium absorption, but evidence linking unabsorbed lactose to infant colic is contradictory. Lactose intolerance symptoms typically appear after age 4-5 in Asian children and can be managed by reducing lactose intake.
population_specificity: Infants, children (particularly Asian populations), and individuals with secondary lactose malabsorption (e.g., due to infections or allergies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess data availability for antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in livestock sectors, particularly ESBL-producing E. coli prevalence in UK dairy cattle, to identify gaps for future research and risk modeling.
results_summary: The study identified data gaps in ESBL E. coli occurrence in beef cattle, bulk tank milk, dairy products, farm environments, and the impact of animal stress on shedding levels, highlighting the need for more robust data before conducting a full quantitative risk assessment.
population_specificity: Dairy cattle in the United Kingdom, with reference to other livestock sectors (beef cattle, pigs, poultry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether new formulations of RUTF using locally available dairy proteins (instead of powdered milk) were acceptable to young children in Ethiopia, Ghana, Pakistan, and India.
results_summary: Local RUTFs were tolerated well in Ethiopia, Ghana, and India, with no increased reports of adverse effects like rash, diarrhea, or vomiting. In Pakistan, children consumed similar quantities but were perceived to enjoy the local RUTF less than the standard version.
population_specificity: Fifty children with moderate wasting in each of the four countries (Ethiopia, Ghana, Pakistan, India).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health relevance of dairy consumption, particularly in lactase non-persistent Asian populations, and determine optimal intake levels based on morbidity and mortality patterns.
results_summary: The study found that modest dairy intake (around one serving per day) is beneficial for reducing all-cause and cardiovascular mortality (especially stroke), overfatness, diabetes, and fracture risks in Asian populations, but excessive consumption is not recommended. No association was found with total cancer mortality in Taiwan, though European populations may experience protective effects.
population_specificity: Primarily lactase non-persistent Asian populations, with specific focus on Taiwan (north-east Asians).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore lactose digestion in humans, its physiological and immunological roles, and the implications of lactase persistence/non-persistence on gastrointestinal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that lactose enhances innate immunity via cathelicidin antimicrobial peptide (CAMP) when lactase activity declines, with synergy from colonic fermentation metabolites like butyrate. Gastrointestinal symptoms in lactase nonpersisters are dose-dependent, typically absent with single lactose intakes ≤25 g/day, and mitigated by spreading intake across the day.
population_specificity: Neonates, infants, and adults (with focus on lactase persistence/non-persistence, particularly northern European ancestry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether commercial heat-treated MFGM could increase resistance to diarrheagenic Escherichia coli in healthy adults.
results_summary: MFGM supplementation reduced E. coli-induced changes in stool frequency and gastrointestinal complaints but did not affect fecal wet weight or E. coli excretion. The study concluded that MFGM may improve resistance to diarrheagenic E. coli.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
effective_dosage: 10 g Lacprodan PL-20 (MFGM-rich milk protein concentrate), twice daily

study_goal: To determine the effects of dairy calcium on changes in body weight and body fat mass in obese women on a weight-loss diet.
results_summary: Increasing dairy intake did not improve weight loss compared to calorie restriction alone. However, plasma total cholesterol decreased and HDL cholesterol increased in intervention groups, and systolic blood pressure was negatively correlated with dairy calcium.
population_specificity: Obese women outpatients at a Nutrition and Diet Clinic in Turkey (mean age 33.10±6.18 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (groups categorized as control, low dairy, and high dairy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of probiotic yogurt (PY) versus standard low-fat yogurt (LF) on weight loss and cardiometabolic risk factors in women during a weight-loss program.
results_summary: Both PY and LF groups showed significant reductions in anthropometric measurements and improvements in cardiometabolic risk factors, but no significant difference in weight loss was observed between groups. The PY group had greater improvements in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, insulin resistance, postprandial glucose, and fasting insulin levels compared to the LF group.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese women (BMI 27-40, age 18-50 years) who regularly consumed low-fat yogurt.
effective_dosage: Consumed daily with main meals (specific quantity not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary saturated fatty acids, particularly from full-fat dairy products, are associated with an increased risk of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found no evidence that dietary saturated fatty acids from varied food sources, including full-fat dairy products, affect the risk of insulin resistance or T2DM. The findings suggest that future research should consider the complexity of the food matrix rather than focusing solely on saturated fat content.
population_specificity: Humans (prospective studies and clinical trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of the DASH diet, which includes low-fat dairy, on metabolic side effects in patients using corticosteroid medications.
results_summary: The DASH diet, including low-fat dairy, significantly improved systolic and diastolic blood pressure, reduced serum total cholesterol, and lowered fasting blood glucose in corticosteroid-treated patients. No significant changes were observed in body weight or waist circumference.
population_specificity: 60 patients on corticosteroid therapy (mean age 31.1 ± 3.6 years, BMI 26.9 ± 2.6 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intake followed DASH guidelines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a fermented, protein-fortified dairy product could increase serum IGF-I levels in women with anorexia nervosa during refeeding.
results_summary: The dairy product slightly increased serum IGF-I levels, with a statistically significant difference in post-hoc analysis, but no significant changes in bone turnover markers were observed.
population_specificity: Women recently admitted with confirmed anorexia nervosa and low baseline serum IGF-I levels.
effective_dosage: 2 daily isocaloric fresh cheese pots containing either 15 g/150 g or 3 g/150 g (controls) of protein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of increased dairy consumption on systemic inflammation and hepatic enzymes in low-dairy consumers with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Increased dairy consumption improved liver function (reduced hepatic enzymes and steatosis index) and reduced systemic inflammation (lower TNF-α and MCP-1 in women, reduced IL-1b and IL-6 gene expression). No significant changes in plasma inflammatory markers were observed overall.
population_specificity: Low-dairy consumers (n = 37) with metabolic syndrome (13 women, 3 men in subset analysis).
effective_dosage: 10 oz 1% milk, 6 oz nonfat yogurt, 4 oz 2% cheese daily (three servings).
study_duration: 6 weeks per dietary period, with a 4-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review infectious risks associated with dairy and other food items, focusing on pathogens less frequently encountered in developed countries.
results_summary: The abstract mentions infectious risks from dairy but does not provide specific findings or outcomes related to dairy safety or efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of exotic food consumers, including dairy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) diagnostics, strain differentiation, and transmission mechanisms in dairy herds.
results_summary: The study highlights the high prevalence of MAP in dairy herds and its adverse impacts on animal health and productivity. It also discusses advancements in molecular techniques for MAP strain differentiation, providing insights into epidemiology and transmission.
population_specificity: Dairy herds and other animal species, including humans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a zero dairy and low glycemic-load diet could prevent new lesions and provide relief in hidradenitis suppurativa.
results_summary: Preliminary observations suggest that a zero dairy and low glycemic-load diet may help prevent new lesions and halt progression of existing ones, even when medications fail. The abstract does not provide detailed statistical results or clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with hidradenitis suppurativa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether excessive dairy consumption might contribute to chronic nasal symptoms in children with unresolved nasal dysfunction.
results_summary: The study suggests that excessive dairy and sugar intake may contribute to chronic nasal symptoms in children who do not respond to standard medical treatments. However, no specific efficacy data or direct causal evidence is provided regarding dairy's role.
population_specificity: Children with persistent nasal obstruction, congestion, and/or rhinorrhea who tested negative for allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of the DASH diet, which includes low-fat dairy, on weight loss and metabolic status in overweight patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: The DASH diet, rich in low-fat dairy, significantly improved weight, BMI, liver enzymes, insulin sensitivity, lipid profiles, and inflammatory/oxidative stress markers compared to the control diet.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary pattern, not isolated dairy intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential link between Mycobacterium avium paratuberculosis (MAP) in dairy cattle and Crohn's disease in humans.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that MAP is widespread in dairy cattle and frequently contaminates food and water, with high detection rates in Crohn's disease patients. However, the study emphasizes that association does not prove causation and calls for further research to confirm or refute the hypothesis.
population_specificity: Patients with Crohn's disease and healthy individuals (North American population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health implications of dairy consumption, addressing common concerns and potential benefits for various populations.
results_summary: Dairy consumption may weakly associate with weight reduction, improved body composition, and bone health benefits. It is well-tolerated by lactose-intolerant individuals when consuming yogurt or hard cheese and does not increase cardiovascular disease risk, especially with low-fat options.
population_specificity: General population, including those with weight management issues, lactose intolerance, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, or cardiovascular disease concerns.
effective_dosage: Up to three servings per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the genetic relatedness between human clinical isolates of *Lactococcus garvieae* and those isolated from meat, dairy, and fish.
results_summary: The study found genetic overlap between human *L. garvieae* isolates and those from dairy, meat, and fish, suggesting these foods might be sources of human infections. Twenty-six sequence types were identified, with four clonal complexes showing predominance, particularly CC3.
population_specificity: Human clinical isolates of *L. garvieae* and isolates from meat, dairy, and fish.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of dairy in food pairing patterns across regional Indian cuisines and its influence on flavor compatibility.
results_summary: Dairy products were found to deviate food pairing towards the positive side, contrasting with spices which contributed to negative food pairing. Dairy emerged as one of the most significant ingredient classes affecting food pairing patterns in regional cuisines.
population_specificity: Recipes from eight different regional cuisines of India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of fructose malabsorption in systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients and assess the impact of a low-fructose diet on digestive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found a 40% prevalence of fructose malabsorption in SSc patients, with a significant correlation between malabsorption and higher digestive symptom scores. A low-fructose diet markedly reduced symptoms in affected patients.
population_specificity: Eighty consecutive patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess dietary deficiencies in South African adults, including dairy intake, to identify malnutrition patterns.
results_summary: The study found dairy to be one of the most commonly deficient food groups in South African adults, attributed to high prices and lack of availability, particularly in poorer urban areas and townships. Rural areas also faced access issues to healthy foods, including dairy.
population_specificity: Adult South Africans (2000–2015)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between dairy consumption and depression risk, as well as its potential role in improving depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that healthy foods, including dairy, were inversely associated with depression risk and may improve depressive symptoms, while high-fat dairy was linked to an increased risk of depression.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from dietary patterns)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether increasing calcium intake through dietary sources (like dairy) or supplements prevents fractures in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no association between dietary calcium, milk, or dairy intake and reduced fracture risk. Calcium supplements showed weak and inconsistent effects, with only one trial in frail elderly women demonstrating significant reductions in fracture risk.
population_specificity: Adults aged over 50, including frail elderly women in residential care with low dietary calcium and vitamin D levels.
effective_dosage: Not specified for dietary sources; calcium supplement dosages varied across trials but were not detailed in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to formulate a carob-based milk beverage and evaluate its chemical and sensory properties.
results_summary: The study found that carob variety and roasting treatment significantly influenced the beverage's chemical properties and sensory acceptability, with roasted carob powder improving phenolic content, antioxidant activity, and sensory ratings.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general population, as no specific demographic was mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12 prototypes were developed, but exact serving sizes or frequencies were not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of sensory testing or intervention was not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent advances in understanding the genetic basis, biological mechanism, diagnosis, and dietary management of lactose intolerance related to dairy consumption.
results_summary: The study found that lactose intolerance is influenced by multiple factors, including lactase expression, lactose dose, and gut microbiota. Dietary management, such as lactose-reduced diets or enzyme replacement, can be effective, but lactose intolerance may also be part of a broader FODMAP intolerance in IBS patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with lactose intolerance, including those with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the association of different glucose-lowering medication classes with angina frequency and nitroglycerin use in patients with type 2 diabetes and stable coronary disease.
results_summary: The study found that patients taking sulfonylureas or insulin had more angina episodes and used more nitroglycerin, while metformin was not associated with angina burden. No direct findings related to dairy were reported.
