population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, documented coronary disease, and a 3-month history of stable angina.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dairy and soy milk consumed either before or together with carbohydrate (bread) on postprandial blood glucose, insulin, and gastric emptying in healthy participants.
results_summary: Co-ingestion of dairy milk with bread lowered postprandial blood glucose and glycemic index, while preloading dairy milk resulted in greater glycemic reduction compared to co-ingestion. Gastric emptying was slower after co-ingesting dairy milk with bread than after the reference meal.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy Chinese male participants
study_duration: Five separate occasions (duration per occasion not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing dairy intake by one serving (200-250 g/d) would slow carotid artery intima-media thickness progression in people with diabetes.
results_summary: The study did not achieve an increase in overall dairy consumption, though yogurt intake was higher in the intervention group at 3 months (not sustained at 12 months). No significant effect on CCA IMT progression was attributed to dairy.
population_specificity: People with well-controlled type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inter-method reliability of the MEDLIFE questionnaire in assessing adherence to a Mediterranean lifestyle, including dairy intake.
results_summary: The study found that low-fat dairy intake was overestimated by the MEDLIFE questionnaire, with only 12% of participants scoring consistently for dairy intake between the MEDLIFE and the full questionnaire.
population_specificity: 196 middle-aged adults (mean age 41.4 ± 9.2 years) living in Madrid, Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the commercial lipid emulsion Fabuless™ promotes short-term satiation and meal termination when consumed with a meal.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that the lipid emulsion suppressed energy intake or triggered faster meal termination compared to energy-matched lipid controls, nor did it affect appetite scores. Both yoghurt preloads suppressed energy intake at breakfast, but the lipid emulsion itself showed no significant effect.
population_specificity: 18 lean men
effective_dosage: 4.2g lipid (0.2MJ) as a 'shot' or combined with dairy yoghurt (1.2MJ)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a Paleolithic diet (excluding dairy) with guideline-based control diets on metabolic syndrome components.
results_summary: The Paleolithic diet showed greater short-term improvements in waist circumference, triglycerides, blood pressure, HDL cholesterol, and fasting blood sugar compared to control diets, but dairy-specific effects were not isolated.
population_specificity: Participants with one or more components of metabolic syndrome (159 total across 4 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risk of opportunistic infections, particularly from Listeria monocytogenes, in patients with inflammatory bowel disease treated with infliximab, and to advise dietary precautions including avoiding certain dairy products.
results_summary: The study reported a case of Listeria meningitis in a patient with ulcerative colitis after infliximab treatment, emphasizing the need to avoid unpasteurized dairy and soft cheeses during anti-TNF therapy.
population_specificity: A 37-year-old man with ulcerative colitis refractory to corticosteroids.
interactions: Avoid soft cheeses and unpasteurized dairy products during anti-TNF therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ability of dairy products to modulate inflammatory processes in humans, focusing on their anti-inflammatory or pro-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: The study found an overall anti-inflammatory activity of dairy products in humans, particularly in subjects with metabolic disorders, while showing pro-inflammatory effects in those allergic to bovine milk. Low-fat, high-fat, and fermented dairy products were associated with anti-inflammatory activity.
population_specificity: Subjects with varying health statuses, including those with metabolic disorders and allergies to bovine milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify lifestyle behavior clusters, including dairy consumption patterns, and their association with cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that the "unhealthy" cluster, which had higher consumption of whole-fat dairy products, was associated with higher waist circumference, TAG levels, systolic blood pressure, and cardiovascular risk compared to healthier clusters. No direct efficacy of dairy was measured, but its inclusion in an unhealthy lifestyle pattern was noted.
population_specificity: 1,327 adults aged 20-80 years from Spain, part of the EVIDENT study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and risk factors of food allergy, including cow's milk and dairy products, in preschool children in Guangdong Province, southern China.
results_summary: The study found that cow's milk and dairy products accounted for 1.9% of adverse food reactions in children, indicating a relatively low but present risk of allergy. A history of food allergy and allergic rhinitis in first-degree relatives were identified as major risk factors.
population_specificity: Preschool children (aged 3-6 years) in Guangdong Province, southern China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of low-fat dairy as part of dietary interventions targeting inflammation and metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The study found that diets including low-fat dairy, alongside other healthy components like fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, are recommended as first-line therapy for MetS. Such diets, including the Mediterranean and DASH diets, have been shown to prevent MetS development and reduce cardiovascular mortality.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk for metabolic syndrome (MetS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of saturated fatty acids (SFAs) in dairy, particularly fermented dairy products, on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and related health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that SFAs in dairy, especially fermented products, have neutral or inverse associations with CVD risk. Replacing SFAs with polyunsaturated fatty acids reduced CVD risk, while replacing them with carbohydrates, particularly sugar, showed no improvement or worsened CVD risk.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a dietary assessment method to measure healthy and sustainable dietary behaviors, including dairy consumption, using a mobile food record application.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding dairy's effects; it focuses on the proposed method to assess dietary behaviors, including dairy, as part of a healthy and sustainable diet.
population_specificity: Australians with diets inconsistent with recommendations, typically low in fruit and vegetables and high in energy-dense nutrient-poor foods and beverages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of toltrazuril treatment on oocyst excretion, diarrhoea score, and weight gain in dairy calves with a history of eimeriosis.
results_summary: Toltrazuril treatment significantly reduced oocyst excretion and improved weight gain in two herds, but no significant effect was observed in the third herd due to management changes. Faecal scores differed between herds but not between treatment groups.
population_specificity: 71 calves aged 48-135 days from three Danish dairy herds with confirmed history of eimeriosis.
effective_dosage: Single oral dose of 15 mg/kg toltrazuril.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of gut microbiota in health and disease and assess the potential of dairy-based interventions (probiotics, prebiotics, fermented dairy) in treating or preventing various disorders.
results_summary: The study found that gut microbiota composition influences postnatal gut function and immune development, with dysbiosis linked to multiple clinical conditions. Modulation of microbiota using dairy-based interventions may help manage disorders like IBS, infectious diarrhea, and allergic diseases.
population_specificity: General discussion of gut microbiota in humans, with implications for infants and individuals with specific conditions (e.g., obesity, autoimmune diseases, allergies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between vegetarian dietary patterns (including dairy) and reduced risk of metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The abstract suggests vegetarian dietary patterns (potentially including dairy) are associated with lower prevalence of MetS, but no specific findings on dairy's effects are provided. Further research is needed to confirm these associations.
population_specificity: General populations, including vegetarians and those at risk for metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a dairy-rich diet as an intervention for reducing adiposity in preschool-age children.
results_summary: One study tested education on a dairy-rich diet and showed a possible effect on adiposity, though the results were not as significant as other interventions like multidisciplinary approaches.
population_specificity: Preschool-age children (0-6 years) who were overweight or obese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bioavailability of carotenoids in dairy products and other foods, focusing on how their natural deposition forms affect absorption.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids in dairy products, which are lipid-dissolved, have high bioavailability, suggesting they are effectively absorbed in the human intestine. This form may serve as a biomimetic model for improving carotenoid formulations in supplements.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human absorption mechanisms discussed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of metabolomics as a tool for assessing dairy intake and clarifying its role in human nutrition and health.
results_summary: The study found that metabolomics can discriminate between consumption of different dairy products and identified potential metabolites related to dairy intake, though further validation is needed for these metabolites to serve as reliable biomarkers.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human nutrition research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dairy as a potential trigger in eosinophilic esophagitis, an immune-mediated condition.
results_summary: The abstract suggests dairy is among the food items commonly implicated in eosinophilic esophagitis, but it does not provide specific findings on dairy's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with eosinophilic esophagitis (no further specificity provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of orally administered bovine anti-H. pylori antibodies in milk for clearing H. pylori infections in O blood group adults.
results_summary: The study found that bovine antibody-containing milk significantly cleared H. pylori in O blood group subjects compared to placebo, with 13 out of 30 treated subjects testing negative, though 3 later reverted to positive. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: H. pylori-infected adults with O blood group.
effective_dosage: Not specified (bovine milk containing antibodies, defatted and pasteurized).
study_duration: 28 days of treatment, 56 days of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of low-fat milk on satiety and energy intake in obese boys compared to apple juice and water.
results_summary: Low-fat milk significantly reduced energy intake at lunch compared to apple juice and water, and obese boys reported higher satiety scores after consuming low-fat milk.
population_specificity: Obese boys aged 10-12 years.
effective_dosage: Fixed content breakfast with low-fat milk (specific amount not detailed).
study_duration: Two consecutive days per intervention beverage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risks posed by VTEC contamination in the agri-food chain, including dairy, and propose management strategies to mitigate these risks.
results_summary: The study highlights that VTEC can contaminate dairy products during production and processing, posing a risk to human health, and emphasizes the need for effective Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) systems to manage this risk.
population_specificity: General human population exposed to VTEC through contaminated dairy and other agri-food products.

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate whether incorporating lean pork into a DASH-style diet (which includes low-fat dairy) affects blood pressure control compared to a diet with chicken and fish.
results_summary: The study found that both DASH-style diets (with lean pork or chicken/fish) similarly reduced blood pressure, indicating that lean pork can be effectively included in a DASH-style diet for BP reduction. Dairy was part of the DASH diet but not the primary focus of the study.
population_specificity: 13 women and 6 men (mean age 61 ± 2 years, BMI 31.2 ± 1.4) with elevated blood pressure.
effective_dosage: Not specified for dairy (55% of total protein intake from lean pork or chicken/fish).
study_duration: Two 6-week dietary interventions with a 4-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the evidence for the use of fermented dairy products, both ingested and topically applied, in modulating skin health and function.
results_summary: The review found limited but positive evidence that fermented dairy products improved skin health in all four included studies, with three focusing on ingestion and one on topical application. However, the studies were few and further research is needed to confirm efficacy and understand mechanisms.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive and therapeutic effects of ozone therapy in ruminants, particularly for treating puerperal diseases and improving fertility in dairy cows and goats.
results_summary: Ozone therapy showed effectiveness in treating reproductive tract lesions, metritis, endometritis, fetal membrane retention, and mastitis, with no adverse effects observed. It also demonstrated advantages over antibiotics in some applications, though limitations like inactivity against intracellular microbes were noted.
population_specificity: Dairy cows and goats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between dietary phosphorus sources (organic vs. inorganic) in dairy and cereals/grains and serum phosphorus concentration.
results_summary: The study found that dairy foods, both with and without inorganic phosphates, significantly increased serum phosphorus levels. Cereals/grains with inorganic phosphates also showed a significant but smaller increase in serum phosphorus.
population_specificity: 7895 adult participants from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2003-2006.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the vitamin B12 content in dairy and other ruminant-derived foods and assess the impact of food processing on vitamin retention.
results_summary: Dairy products contain lower vitamin B12 concentrations compared to ruminant offal like liver and kidney. The B12 content in bovine milk remains stable across breeds, feed, seasons, and lactation stages, but processing (e.g., thermal treatment) reduces B12 levels.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cardioprotective mechanisms of dairy and its potential to reduce cardiovascular disease risk through dietary modification.
results_summary: Acute dairy intake showed benefits on vascular function without blood pressure improvements, while chronic interventions yielded mixed results. Dairy's vasoprotective effects may involve nitric oxide bioavailability, oxidative stress, inflammation, and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general population, given the public health context).
study_duration: Short-term (≤2 weeks) for acute studies; chronic intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether the effects of milk fat on plasma lipids and cardiometabolic risk markers are modulated by the milk fat globule membrane (MFGM) content.
results_summary: The study found that milk fat enclosed by MFGM (whipping cream) did not impair the lipoprotein profile, unlike milk fat without MFGM (butter oil), which increased plasma lipids. Nineteen genes were differentially regulated between groups, mostly correlating with lipid changes.
population_specificity: Overweight men and women (n = 57).
effective_dosage: 40 g milk fat/day as either whipping cream or butter oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of dairy proteins (casein and whey) in reducing the risk and improving insulin secretion in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Epidemiologic studies suggest dairy products reduce T2DM risk, and clinical evidence indicates dairy proteins may improve insulin secretion in T2DM patients. However, existing studies are limited to acute effects and lack long-term data on prevention, management, or treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a dairy drink enriched with ω-3 LC-PUFA could impact the lipid profiles of mothers and newborns and influence visual and cognitive development in newborns.
results_summary: The enriched dairy drink increased DHA levels in mothers and newborns and raised nervonic acid ratios but showed no significant effects on visual or cognitive/psychomotor development, except for a shorter latency in visual response in boys.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their newborns.
effective_dosage: 400 mL/day of the fish oil-enriched dairy drink (containing ~400 mg EPA-DHA/day).
study_duration: From pregnancy through lactation (timing not explicitly stated, but measurements were taken at delivery and up to 12 months postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare different image texture description methods for analyzing yogurt protein networks using confocal scanning laser microscopy (CSLM).
results_summary: The study found that texton-based descriptors provided a more comprehensive description of yogurt protein network images compared to gray-level co-occurrence matrix descriptors and fractal analysis, while remaining practical and tunable.
population_specificity: Yogurt samples with varied production factors (fat content, protein content, heat treatment, and incubation temperature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a calcium-rich dairy-based pre-exercise meal could mitigate exercise-induced bone calcium loss in female cyclists.
results_summary: The study found that a calcium-rich dairy meal (~1350 mg calcium) consumed before cycling significantly attenuated the rise in bone resorption markers (PTH and CTX-I) compared to a low-calcium control meal, suggesting a protective effect on bone calcium homeostasis during exercise. No significant effects were observed for bone formation markers (CTX-II and PINP).
population_specificity: 32 well-trained female cyclists
study_duration: Two 90-minute cycling trials separated by 1 day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of vitamin D-fortified milk on circulating 25(OH)D concentrations and compliance with fortified dairy among Tehran students.
results_summary: The study evaluated the impact of different doses of vitamin D-fortified milk on serum vitamin D levels in adolescents, suggesting potential efficacy but noted the need for further research on bone health outcomes and safety.
population_specificity: 15- to 19-year-old guidance and high school students of both genders from different districts of Tehran.
effective_dosage: Whole milk, milk with 600 IU vitamin D/1000cc, or milk with 1000 IU vitamin D/1000cc.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the effects of a Mediterranean diet (low in dairy) on cognitive decline in healthy older adults, not specifically evaluating dairy's safety or efficacy.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific findings regarding dairy's effects, as the focus was on the Mediterranean diet's impact on cognitive performance and biomarkers.
population_specificity: Healthy Australian men and women aged 65 years and above with normal cognitive function.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dairy consumption was minimized as part of the Mediterranean diet intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether non-dairy calcium-fortified cereal bars could effectively increase calcium intake in women who may avoid dairy due to lactose intolerance, allergies, or preferences.
results_summary: The study found that consuming two calcium-fortified cereal bars daily (400 mg calcium/day) significantly increased dietary calcium intake without increasing total energy intake or causing weight gain. The intervention was more effective than the control or baseline diets in boosting calcium levels.
population_specificity: 35 healthy women over 18 years old.
effective_dosage: 2 calcium-fortified cereal bars daily (total 400 mg calcium/day).
study_duration: 3 weeks per intervention phase (with a 3-week baseline and crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine changes in Salmonella subtypes on Michigan dairy farms over time and their association with human illnesses.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in Salmonella subtypes on dairy farms between 2000-2001 and 2009, with a shift from multidrug-resistant to pansusceptible strains. Human illnesses linked to bovine-derived Salmonella decreased for older strains but increased for newer ones.
population_specificity: Michigan dairy farms and associated human illnesses in Michigan.
study_duration: Sampled in 2000-2001 and again in 2009; human illness data from 2001-2012.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the population attributable risk (PAR) of low calcium from dairy products on hip fracture incidence in Norway.
results_summary: Low calcium from dairy products had negligible PAR estimates, indicating it was of less importance in contributing to hip fractures compared to other factors like low physical activity and smoking.
population_specificity: Norwegian population, particularly those at risk for hip fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the taxonomic complexity, antimicrobial susceptibilities, and probiotic use of Lactobacillus species in dairy products, particularly their potential role in preventing Clostridium difficile infection.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus species are generally acid-resistant and survive ingestion, but their antimicrobial susceptibilities vary widely, with some species resistant to common antibiotics like metronidazole and vancomycin. Their use as probiotics is widespread, but concurrent antibiotic use may affect their survival and efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human gastrointestinal and vaginal flora context).
interactions: Concurrent antibiotic use may affect Lactobacillus survival.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a combination therapy (rebamipide + rabeprazole) versus rabeprazole alone in healing artificial ulcers post-endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD).
results_summary: The combination therapy (reb+PPI) showed a higher ulcer area reduction ratio and faster progression to healing stages compared to PPI monotherapy, particularly in the early stages post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with ESD-derived artificial ulcers.
effective_dosage: Rebamipide 300 mg daily + rabeprazole 20 mg daily for the first 4 weeks, followed by rebamipide alone for the remaining 4 weeks.

study_goal: To determine if vitamin D and calcium-fortified yogurts reduce serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) and bone resorption markers more effectively than non-fortified yogurts in elderly women at risk of fractures.
results_summary: Fortified yogurts significantly increased serum 25OHD, reduced PTH, and lowered bone resorption markers (TRAP5b and CTX) compared to non-fortified yogurts. The effects were statistically significant for TRAP5b and nearly significant for CTX.
population_specificity: White women over 60 years (mean age 73.4) at risk of fragility fractures.
effective_dosage: 10 µg vitamin D3/day and 520 mg calcium/day (total 800 mg/day) via two 125 g servings of yogurt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health effects and underlying mechanisms of dairy products, including fermented products, as part of a healthy dietary pattern for preventing and treating cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that dairy products, including fermented products, have unique health benefits that support their inclusion in a healthy dietary pattern for preventing and treating CVD and T2DM. The abstract highlights compelling scientific evidence for the health effects of dairy but does not specify detailed outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular benefits of dairy products as part of dietary patterns with high evidence for cardioprotective effects.
results_summary: The study found that dairy products are among the foods with the highest evidence for beneficial effects on cardiovascular outcomes, including reduced risk of coronary artery disease and stroke, and improvements in intermediate risk markers like cholesterol and blood pressure.
population_specificity: General population with a focus on cardiovascular health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of hCG administration 4 or 6 days after timed AI on progesterone (P4) concentration and pregnancy outcomes in repeat breeding dairy cows.
results_summary: Administering hCG 6 days post TAI improved pregnancy rates (38.9% vs. 30.9% in controls) and reduced pregnancy losses (15.0% vs. 37.7% in controls). The treatment also increased plasma P4 concentration and showed seasonal and parity-specific benefits.
population_specificity: Repeat breeding dairy cows (primiparous and multiparous).
effective_dosage: 1500 IU hCG administered once either 4 or 6 days post TAI.
study_duration: Intervention was a single dose, with outcomes measured up to 45 days post TAI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of calcium from different sources (including dairy) on serum calcium and phosphate levels to assess potential differences in cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The study found that a dairy product meal resulted in smaller elevations in serum ionised and total calcium compared to calcium citrate fasting, and increased serum phosphate and calcium-phosphate product. These differences suggest dietary calcium (from dairy) may have a safer acute effect on serum calcium than supplements.
population_specificity: Ten women with a mean age of 69 years.
effective_dosage: 500 mg of calcium as a single dose.
study_duration: Blood was sampled over 6 hours post-intervention, with at least 6 days between each intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a diet rich in branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) from whey protein would increase BCAA catabolism and reduce fasting plasma BCAA concentrations in obese women with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in plasma BCAA concentrations between the whey and gelatin protein groups post-intervention. BCAA metabolism was only modestly affected by whey protein supplementation at 20 g/d, and the association between BCAAs and insulin resistance was lost after the intervention.
population_specificity: Obese women with metabolic syndrome (n=27).
effective_dosage: 20 g/d of whey or gelatin protein supplement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors influencing weight loss variability during energy restriction, specifically examining the role of dairy consumption in an energy-restricted diet.
results_summary: High-responders to energy restriction showed greater reductions in body weight, BMI, and fat mass, with unique blood metabolite signatures and differences in physical activity levels compared to low-responders. The study did not focus on adverse effects but highlighted metabolic and physical activity differences between groups.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-dairy diet versus a high-lean red meat diet on insulin sensitivity in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that a high-dairy diet reduced insulin sensitivity compared to a high-lean red meat diet, particularly in women, with no significant difference in men. Fasting insulin levels were higher after the dairy diet, but fasting glucose remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese men and women, some with impaired fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high consumption of primarily low-fat dairy from milk, yogurt, or custard).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how dietary polyphenols modulate gut microbiota and their potential health benefits, particularly in the context of dairy fermented foods.
results_summary: The study found that dietary polyphenols may promote intestinal health by stimulating beneficial bacteria (e.g., lactobacilli and bifidobacteria) and inhibiting pathogenic bacteria, suggesting prebiotic-like effects. Combining in vitro and in vivo models could help clarify these mechanisms and their implications for human health.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of experimental approaches, including batch cultures, simulators, animal models, and human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein and medium-chain saturated fatty acids (MC-SFAs) supplementation improved postprandial lipid metabolism in individuals with abdominal obesity.
results_summary: Whey protein reduced postprandial chylomicron response (apoB-48) compared to casein, suggesting a potential cardiovascular benefit. Casein increased postprandial GLP-1 response, but no significant effects were observed on other lipid or metabolic markers.
population_specificity: Adults with abdominal obesity (n=52 completed the study).
effective_dosage: 60 g milk protein (whey or casein) and 63 g milk fat (high or low MC-SFA content) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of lactic acid bacteria (LAB) and bifidobacteria probiotics on inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) through a systematic review of human clinical trials.
results_summary: Probiotics and synbiotics showed positive effects in treating and maintaining ulcerative colitis (UC), while synbiotics alone demonstrated clear effectiveness for Crohn's disease (CD). Probiotics also improved clinical symptoms in associated IBD conditions like pouchitis and cholangitis, though more research is needed to understand their mechanisms.
population_specificity: Human subjects with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease (CD), ulcerative colitis (UC), pouchitis, and cholangitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding non-fat dairy products to the normal diet reduces central blood pressure and improves vascular function in middle-aged and older adults with elevated blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that adding non-fat dairy products reduced central systolic blood pressure and improved vascular function, while removing dairy products worsened vascular function. The High Dairy condition showed significant improvements in multiple vascular health markers.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults (mean age 53 ± 2 years) with elevated blood pressure.
effective_dosage: +4 servings/day of conventional non-fat dairy products.
study_duration: 4 weeks per dietary condition, with a 2-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased dairy protein intake, combined with resistance training, enhanced strength gains in older adults compared to soy protein or usual protein intake.
results_summary: The study found that increased dairy protein intake led to greater strength gains compared to soy protein, with no significant differences in lean mass, physical function, or mental health scores between groups. Soy protein attenuated strength gains relative to dairy protein and usual protein intake.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (mean age 61.5 ± 7.4 years, BMI 27.6 ± 3.6 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: High dairy protein (HP-D) >1.2 g/kg body weight/day (~27 g/day dairy protein), delivered at each main meal or post-resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of dairy-derived components (e.g., tryptophan, glycine) in addressing climacteric symptoms like hot flashes, sleep disorders, and irritability.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that dairy components like tryptophan and glycine may influence serotonin synthesis and sleep quality, potentially mitigating climacteric symptoms, but no direct dairy-specific outcomes are reported.
population_specificity: Peri- and post-menopausal women experiencing climacteric symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not specified for dairy components; resveratrol (3-10 micromoles) and other nutrients mentioned but not dairy-specific.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of milk proteins (skimmed milk, whey, casein) and water on body composition and leptin levels in overweight adolescents.
results_summary: Milk proteins increased lean mass index (LMI) but also fat mass index (FMI) and leptin levels, while water only increased LMI without affecting FMI or leptin.
population_specificity: Overweight adolescents aged 12-15 years.
effective_dosage: 1 L/day of skimmed milk, whey, casein (35 g protein/L), or water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on the association between cheese intake and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with most prospective studies reporting no association between cheese intake and CVD risk, while others showed either increased or decreased risk. Intervention studies indicated no harmful effect on cholesterol levels when comparing cheese fat to butter fat.
population_specificity: General human population (varied study designs including intervention, prospective, case-control, and cross-sectional studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize epidemiological findings on the relationship between dairy product consumption and metabolic syndrome (MetS) and explore potential physiological mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that dairy constituents like calcium, protein, and fat may positively influence MetS components through mechanisms such as fatty acid binding, satiety enhancement, and blood pressure reduction, though low-fat dairy is recommended to limit saturated fat intake. More research is needed to fully understand these effects.
population_specificity: Observational studies and randomized controlled trials involving general populations (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a maternal diet rich in full-fat dairy products increases milk lipid content and alters gene expression related to lipid synthesis or uptake in lactating women.
results_summary: The study found that milk fat percentage was higher with full-fat dairy consumption compared to low-fat dairy, and over 20 fatty acid concentrations differed. However, no changes in gene expression related to lipid synthesis or uptake were detected.
population_specificity: 15 healthy lactating women
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets enriched in full-fat or nonfat dairy products)
study_duration: 14 days per diet with a 2-week washout period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of low-fat or nonfat dairy products in managing gout and reducing recurrent flares.
results_summary: The study found that consumption of low-fat or nonfat dairy products should be encouraged to help reduce the likelihood of recurrent gout flares, alongside other dietary modifications.
population_specificity: Patients with gout or at risk of recurrent gout flares.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dietary patterns in a Spanish population and assess their relationship with plasma lipid profiles, including the impact of a Western dietary pattern high in dairy.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to a Western dietary pattern (high in dairy, red meat, fast food, and cereals) was associated with lower high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels and increased risk of suboptimal lipid profiles compared to a Mediterranean dietary pattern.
population_specificity: 1290 participants from the Aragon Workers Health Study cohort in Spain.
study_duration: Habitual intake over the past 12 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reasons for the growing consumer preference for plant-based milk substitutes over dairy, including medical and lifestyle factors, and to assess the technological and nutritional aspects of these substitutes.
results_summary: The study found that plant-based milk substitutes are chosen due to lactose intolerance (75% global prevalence), cow's milk allergy, and affordability in regions where mammal milk is scarce. However, many substitutes have sensory drawbacks and varying nutritional profiles, with some being low in protein and calcium, necessitating consumer awareness when replacing dairy.
population_specificity: Consumers with lactose intolerance, cow's milk allergy, or those opting for plant-based substitutes for lifestyle or economic reasons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dietary patterns, including low-fat dairy, on infant birthweight.
results_summary: Consumption of whole foods such as low-fat dairy during pregnancy appears beneficial for appropriate birthweight, though specific efficacy data for dairy alone is not isolated.
population_specificity: Pregnant women

study_goal: The researchers were reviewing potential treatments for Clostridium difficile infection (CDI), including alternative antibiotics, bacteriocins, and vaccines, but did not focus on Dairy.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the efficacy of various treatments for CDI, such as fidaxomicin, rifaximin, and faecal microbiota transplantation, but does not mention Dairy or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on CDI treatments, not Dairy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify effective behavioral interventions to increase calcium intake in pregnant, lactating, or post-partum women.
results_summary: The review identified five behavioral interventions, with only one showing a large effect size (mean change of 954 mg of calcium per day). The number of behavioral change techniques did not correlate with efficacy, and only one study used a theoretical framework.
population_specificity: Pregnant, lactating, or post-partum women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between dietary changes involving low-fat and high-fat dairy and improvements in metabolic syndrome components in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Meeting low-fat dairy goals was associated with lower diastolic blood pressure and higher HDL cholesterol, while meeting high-fat dairy goals increased the probability of normal fasting glucose. Exclusion of high-fat dairy reduced the risk of impaired fasting glucose by 60%.
population_specificity: Mexican postmenopausal women with metabolic syndrome (n = 118).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how changes in dairy intake affected serum concentrations of essential elements (magnesium, zinc, copper, and selenium) in participants following different dietary interventions.
results_summary: The study found that increasing dairy consumption was associated with elevated serum copper levels (β = 0.320, p = 0.039) in the low-carbohydrate diet group at 12 months. No significant associations were observed in the Mediterranean or low-fat diet groups.
population_specificity: 231 participants (85% male, mean age 52 years, mean BMI 32.8 kg/m²) from the DIRECT study, randomized to low-fat, Mediterranean, or low-carbohydrate diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether maternally administered creatine (obtained from dairy, fish, or meat) during pregnancy could provide fetal neuroprotection and reduce adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes.
results_summary: No randomized controlled trials were found to evaluate creatine's effects for fetal neuroprotection in human pregnancy, so no conclusions could be drawn regarding its efficacy or safety. Animal studies suggest potential benefits, but human data is lacking.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (human studies not conducted; animal studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the probiotic Lactobacillus plantarum TENSIA, consumed via cheese or yoghurt, could lower blood pressure and influence other health biomarkers, regardless of food matrix properties.
results_summary: The study found that consuming L. plantarum TENSIA in cheese or yoghurt significantly lowered systolic and diastolic blood pressure without affecting BMI, plasma glucose, lipid levels, or inflammatory markers. The effects were consistent regardless of the food matrix or baseline blood pressure and BMI values.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
effective_dosage: 1×10^10 cfu daily in cheese or 6×10^9 cfu daily in yoghurt

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary patterns, including a diet rich in low-fat dairy (DASH diet), on headache occurrence compared to a control diet.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in headache occurrence between the DASH diet (rich in low-fat dairy) and the control diet at any sodium level. However, reduced sodium intake was associated with a lower risk of headaches, regardless of dietary pattern.
population_specificity: 390 participants in a multicentre feeding study in the USA.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary patterns rather than isolated dairy intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between the Mediterranean diet (including moderate dairy consumption) and the risk of gastrointestinal cancers.
results_summary: The study found that the Mediterranean diet, which includes moderate dairy consumption, is associated with a significant reduction in the risk of gastrointestinal cancers, though decisive evidence for its adjuvant treatment effect is lacking.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on gastrointestinal cancer risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of tailored lifestyle interventions, including low-fat dairy consumption, in reducing blood pressure and improving health outcomes among rural women with prehypertension.
results_summary: The study found that both web-based and print-mailed intervention groups showed significant improvements in low-fat dairy consumption compared to the standard advice group (p < .001 and p = .002, respectively). These improvements contributed to overall better dietary outcomes and blood pressure reduction.
population_specificity: Rural women aged 40-69 with prehypertension.
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of a broader dietary intervention).
